articles.title: About
articles.contents:
Professional Goals
drhgber
I hope to be admitted to a graduate school program for Fall 2023 studying varying aspects of language including prosody, aphasia, individual differences, and language processing and comprehension. I am interested in both typical and atypical populations.
Honors Thesis
High Rising Terminals as a Function of Gender, Race, and Social Status
High Rising Terminals (HRTs) are a speech feature where there is a rising intonation contour at the end of an utterance where a falling intonation contour would normally be used. Commonly referred to as “uptalk” or “upspeak,” they are lumped together with other negative politeness devices, and proposed to be used as a way for women to make themselves seem less imposing. As a result of this, HRTs are colloquially seen as a sign of uncertainty in female speakers. Despite this common notion, HRTs are used for a range of purposes in conversation. They may signal a topic change, or be used as a way to gauge the listener’s responsiveness or understanding. This project investigated the interplay between race, gender, and social status in the interpretation of HRTs.
Volante, C. (2022). High Rising Terminals as a Function of Gender, Race, and Social Status. Retrieved from https://purl.lib.fsu.edu/diginole/honors_thesis_submission-ee987f19-7d37-4641-aeb0-e7f9ed928339
This work has been presented at:
Women in Math, Science, and Engineering Spring Research Symposium (2021, 2022)
Florida State University Undergraduate Research Symposium (2022)
The Psychonomic Society 63rd Annual Meeting (2022)

articles.title: Caitlin Volante
articles.contents:
Caitlin Volante
          
          
          Home
          About
          CV
          ☰
          
          
      
        
          
            Caitlin Volante
          
          
            
              I am a fourth year senior at Florida State University
              getting my Bachelors in Behavioral Neuroscience. I
              currently work in Dr. Michael Kaschak’s Language, Memory,
              and Learning Lab studying High Rising Terminals
              interpretation, and in Dr. Brad Schmidt ABHC Lab where we
              use EEG as a way to measure PTSD and design new
              interventions.
